etymology.description: 小 (little) + 皇帝 (emperor) = indulged child treated like royalty.
etymology.interpretation: Metaphor likening an overindulged child—often an only child—to a “little emperor,” especially noted in one‑child‑policy-era families. Conveys pampering, entitlement, and domineering behavior at home.

examples.chinese: 很多家庭把独生子女当成小皇帝(很多家庭把獨生子女當成小皇帝)。
examples.pinyin: Hěn duō jiātíng bǎ dúshēng zǐnǚ dāngchéng xiǎo huángdì.
examples.english: Many families treat their only child as a little emperor.

examples.chinese: 他被大人宠坏了(他被大人寵壞了)，行为像个小皇帝(行為像個小皇帝)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bèi dàrén chǒng huài le, xíngwéi xiàng gè xiǎo huángdì.
examples.english: He’s been spoiled by adults and behaves like a little emperor.

examples.chinese: 老师担心“家里的小皇帝”在学校难以适应(老師擔心「家裡的小皇帝」在學校難以適應)。
examples.pinyin: Lǎoshī dānxīn “jiālǐ de xiǎo huángdì” zài xuéxiào nányǐ shìyìng.
examples.english: The teacher worries that the ‘little emperor’ at home will struggle to adapt at school.
